【0】INDICATIONS:  ___ man with small cell lung cancer with evidence of
【1】recurrent disease, having liver and bone lesions on outside PET.
【2】
【3】COMPARISONS:  Limited comparison to outside PET-CT scan from ___,
【4】from ___ Imaging, as scanned into the ___ PACS.
【5】
【6】TECHNIQUE:  Following a non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen, axial CT images
【7】of the chest, abdomen and pelvis were obtained with oral and intravenous
【8】contrast.  Sagittal and coronal reformations of the torso were performed.
【9】Additional delayed three-minute images through the level of the kidneys only
【10】were also obtained.
【11】
【12】CT OF THE CHEST WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST:  There are multiple enlarged
【13】mediastinal lymph nodes suspicious for metastatic disease.  These are
【14】considerably larger than on a prior PET-CT.  Representative is a right
【15】paratracheal lymph node measuring 21 x 13 mm (4:22), compared to only 13 x 7
【16】mm previously.  There is no axillary lymphadenopathy, but a conglomerate of
【17】left supraclavicular lymph nodes measures 21 x 13 mm (4:8), also progressed.
【18】
【19】There are no pleural or pericardial effusions.  Coronary artery calcifications
【20】are noted.  Otherwise, the heart, great vessels and pericardium are
【21】unremarkable.  There is moderate to severe predominantly centrilobular
【22】emphysema, most pronounced in the lung apices.
【23】
【24】There is also a mass in the left upper lobe which measures 24 x 18 mm (4:28),
【25】compared to only 17 x 13 mm before.  There is focal atelectasis and/or
【26】scarring in the right middle and lower lobes, but no other definite suspicious
【27】findings.
【28】
【29】CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH AND WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST.  There are multiple
【30】liver masses consistent with metastases.  The largest measures 24 mm in
【31】diameter (4:58) and is located in segment IV.  This lesion measured
【32】approximately 17 mm in diameter previously.
【33】
【34】The gallbladder, adrenal glands, spleen and pancreas are unremarkable, noting
【35】some fatty infiltration of the pancreas.  Enlarged celiac lymph nodes are
【36】present, the largest measuring 36 x 15 mm (4:63), considerably larger than
【37】before.
【38】
【39】Simple cysts are present in the kidneys bilaterally, as well as a small 7 mm
【40】hyperdense cyst in the interpolar region of the left kidney. Sigmoid
【41】diverticulosis is noted. Otherwise, the stomach, small and large bowel are
【42】within normal limits.
【43】
【44】There is a small abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring up to 24 mm in diameter
【45】with atherosclerotic calcifications, also involving the common iliac arteries
【46】and their major tributaries.
【47】
【48】CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  Prostate calcifications are noted on a
【49】mildly enlarged gland.  The bladder, sigmoid and rectum are within normal
【50】limits.  There is no lymphadenopathy or ascites.
【51】
【52】BONE WINDOWS:  There are no definite bony lesions.  There is a focus of
【53】slightly reduced bony density along the right posterolateral aspect of the T12
【54】vertebral body, which may be degenerative in either etiology or due to
【55】rarefaction. A similar site is located within L2. Subtle metastases
【56】cannot be excluded and would have been better evaluate with the prior PET-CT
【57】with direct correlation of the PET and CT images. There are degenerative
【58】changes of the facets in the lower lumbar spine.
【59】
【60】IMPRESSION:
【61】1. Progression of metastatic disease, including increased dominant lung mass,
【62】progressive mediastinal and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, and liver
【63】metastases.
【64】
【65】2. No definite bone metastases, noting faint lytic foci in T12 and L2 of
【66】questionable significance.  If it would change management to better assess for
【67】the possibility of osseous metastases, correlation with the prior outside PET-
【68】CT images with direct overlay of the CT and PET images, or alternatively bone
【69】scan, is suggested.

【11】TECHNIQUE:  Axial T1, proton density, T2 fat sat, coronal T1, T2 fat sat,
【12】gradient echo, sagittal T2-weighted sequences through the left wrist were
【13】obtained on a 1.5 Tesla magnet.  The patient declined gadolinium
【14】administration.
【15】
【16】FINDINGS:  Evaluation of bone marrow signal demonstrates a T1 dark, T2
【17】hyperintense 8-mm lesion in the distal ulna (6:8), which is consistent with 
【18】myeloma deposit.  Additional signal intensity abnormalities are seen in the
【19】capitate, hamate, triquetrum, trapezium and trapezoid.  The signal intensity
【20】characteristics are similar, these may represent additional myelomatous
【21】lesions.  In addition, degenerative changes with spur formation present at the
【22】first ___ joint with subjacent bone marrow edema. 
【23】
【24】There is a small osseous fragment adjacent to the ulnar styloid consistent
【25】with an unutited fracture. 
【26】
【27】Evaluation of the extensor tendons demonstrates tenosynovitis and abnormal
【28】signal consistent with tendinopathy in all six extensor compartments.  The
【29】abnormality is most pronounced in the extensor digitorum compartment, where
【30】there is large amount of fluid surrounding the tendons, and one of the
【31】extensor digitorum tendons demonstrates markedly thickened up to 6 mm and
【32】markedly abnormal in signal intensity, in keeping with severe tendinopathy and
【33】high-grade partial tear.  The extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor digiti minimi,
【34】extensor carpi ulnaris and radialis, extensor pollicis longus, adductor
【35】pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis demonstrate increased signal
【36】intensity, consistent with tendinopathy.

【39】tendons are abnormal in intrinsic signal intensity, consistent with
【40】tendinopathy.  There is severe bowing of the flexor retinaculum, with expanded
【41】abnormal appearance of the medial nerve at the point of maximal expansion. 
【42】The ulnar nerve demonstrates abnormal increased in size as well.
【43】
【44】Evaluation of the intrinsic carpal ligaments demonstrates intact lunate
【45】triquetrum ligament.  
【46】
【47】There is abnormal signal intensity in the region of the scapholunate ligament,

【50】The radial attachment of the triangular fibrocartilage is intact.  There is an
【51】abnormal signal and lack of normal attachment in the fovea and styloid sites,
【52】which are concerning for a tear.  
【53】

【56】fluid in the distal radioulnar joint.

【60】consistent with severe tendinopathy/high grade partial tear.  Less pronounced
【61】tendinopathy and synovitis in the remainder extensor tendons. 
【62】
【63】2.  Severe tenosynovitis and tendinopathy involving the flexor tendons.

【65】in ___ canal.
【66】

【0】INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with alcoholic cirrhosis , with actively
【1】bleeding gastric varices seen on EGD today  // needs embolization of gastric
【2】varix     . The CTA performed just prior to the interventional radiology
【3】procedure showed contrast extravasation during a late arterial/portal venous
【4】phase. Since it was unclear if this was arterial or portal venous upper GI
【5】bleeding, a decision was made to begin with an arteriogram and check a portal
【6】venogram if needed.
【7】
【8】COMPARISON:  CTA from ___.
【9】
【10】TECHNIQUE:  OPERATORS: Dr. ___ radiology fellow) and Dr.
【11】___ radiology attending) performed the procedure.  The
【12】attending, Dr. ___ was present and supervising throughout the procedure.
【13】ANESTHESIA:  The patient was intubated and sedated by the ICU team. 1%
【14】lidocaine was injected in the skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the
【15】access sites.
【16】MEDICATIONS:
【17】CONTRAST: 330 ml of Optiray contrast.
【18】FLUOROSCOPY TIME AND DOSE:  80 min, 3678 mGy
【19】
【20】PROCEDURE:  1. Right common femoral artery access.
【21】2. Celiac arteriogram.
【22】3. Left gastric arteriogram.
【23】4. Left gastric Gel-Foam and coil embolization.
【24】5. Paraumbilical venogram.
【25】6. Direct portal venogram.
【26】7. Left gastric variceal embolization.
【27】8. Short gastric vein embolization.
【28】9. Right common femoral arteriogram and Angioseal closure.
【29】10. Portal vein and superior vena cava pressures.
【30】
【31】PROCEDURE DETAILS:
【32】Following the discussion of the risks, benefits and alternatives to the
【33】procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the health care proxy.
【34】The patient was then brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the
【35】exam table.  A pre-procedure time-out was performed per ___ protocol.  Both
【36】groins and the abdomen were prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
【37】
【38】Using palpatory and fluoroscopic guidance, the right common femoral artery was
【39】punctured using a micropuncture set at the level of the mid-femoral head. A
【40】0.018 wire was passed easily into the vessel lumen. A small skin incision was
【41】made over the needle. Then the inner dilator and wire were removed and a
【42】___ wire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the aorta. The micropuncture
【43】sheath was exchanged for a 5 ___ sheath which was attached to a continuous
【44】heparinized saline side arm flush.
【45】A C2 Cobra catheter was advanced over ___ wire into the aorta and used
【46】to select the left external iliac artery. The catheter was then exchanged for
【47】___ catheter which was formed in the bifurcation. The wire was removed
【48】and the celiac artery was selectively cannulated and a small contrast
【49】injection was made to confirm position. A celiac arteriogram was performed.
【50】The ___ catheter was then withdrawn to select the left gastric artery
【51】and a left gastric arteriogram was performed. Next a micro catheter was
【52】advanced through the ___ into the left gastric artery and Gel-Foam and
【53】coil embolization was performed. A repeat arteriogram showed no evidence of
【54】flow through the left gastric artery.
【55】Given the patient has persistent symptoms, a decision was made to perform a
【56】direct portal venogram to evaluate for varices. After injection of 1%
【57】lidocaine, under ultrasound guidance, a paraumbilical vein was accessed using
【58】a micropuncture set. Contrast injection showed the small vein communicating
【59】with the portal vein however access to the portal vein could not be achieved
【60】with a widened catheter. The access was then removed and a purse-string suture
【61】was sheath placed for hemostasis.
【62】Next under direct ultrasound guidance, a 21 gauge needle was advanced into the
【63】peripheral portal vein. The needle was exchanged for a Accustick sheath over a
【64】Nitinol wire. Using the ___ wire, the sheath was upsized to a 5 ___
【65】sheath. A portal venogram was performed through a straight flush catheter.
【66】Based on the results of the venogram, it was decided to embolize the varices.
【67】The straight flush catheter was exchanged for a Sos catheter. The micro
【68】catheter was then advanced and embolization was performed with approximately
【69】10 mL of dehydrated alcohol. This was complemented by placement of metallic
【70】coils as well. The Sos catheter was then advanced into another branch of the
【71】left gastric vein and coil and alcohol embolization was performed.
【72】
【73】Once a satisfactory result was obtained, the catheter was then removed over
【74】the wire and the portal venous sheath was removed following tract embolization
【75】using Gel-Foam. A right common femoral arteriogram was performed through the
【76】femoral artery sheath. An Angio-Seal device was deployed in the right common
【77】femoral artery and manual pressure was held until hemostasis was achieved. 
【78】Sterile dressings were applied.   The patient tolerated the procedure well.
【79】
【80】FINDINGS: 
【81】
【82】1.  Large left gastric artery supplying the gastric esophageal junction, which
【83】is the expected site of bleeding.  A celiac arteriogram provided information
【84】about the location of the left gastric artery for catheterization.
【85】2. Successful Gel-Foam and coil embolization of the left gastric artery with
【86】stasis on repeat arteriogram.
【87】3. Right common femoral arteriogram showing conventional femoral arterial
【88】anatomy amenable to Angio-Seal deployment.
【89】4. Paraumbilical venogram showing small vessels leading into the portal vein
【90】which could not be catheterized.
【91】5. Direct portal venogram showing large left gastric varices supplying the
【92】area of the gastroesophageal junction.
【93】6. Successful alcohol and coil embolization of left gastric and short gastric
【94】variceal branches supplying the area of interest.
【95】7. Gel-Foam tract embolization of the portal venous access site.
【96】8. Manometry showing a portal vein pressure of 40 mmHg and the superior vena
【97】cava pressure of 29 mmHg (via the central line) resulting in a portosystemic
【98】gradient of 11. Based on the results of manometry in conjunction with the
【99】patient's MELD score, a decision was made to embolize primarily rather than to
【100】place a TIPS.
【101】
【102】IMPRESSION: 
【103】
【104】Successful embolization of left gastric varices and the left gastric artery.

【10】

【14】the dedicated anesthesia note for further details.  In addition, the patient
【15】received 1 g of ceftriaxone prior to procedure.
【16】
【17】PROCEDURES:
【18】1.  Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography.
【19】2.  Snaring of an indwelling plastic biliary stent and removal via the
【20】percutaneous access.
【21】3.  Placement of a 10 ___ internal-external drain.
【22】
【23】PROCEDURE DETAILS:
【24】
【25】Following discussion of the risks, benefits and alternatives to the procedure,
【26】informed written patient consent was obtained.  The patient was brought to the
【27】angiographic suite and placed supine on the table.  A preprocedure timeout was
【28】performed using three patient identifiers.  General anesthesia was induced in
【29】the angiographic suite.  The skin of the anterior abdominal wall was prepped
【30】and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  Multiple passes were made with a
【31】Cook 21-gauge needle to opacify the biliary tree.  Initially, we attempted to
【32】access using ultrasound; however, this was unsuccessful, therefore, the tract
【33】was opacified under fluoroscopic guidance.  Injection of contrast demonstrated
【34】moderately dilated intrahepatic duct with an indwelling stent seen in the
【35】common hepatic duct extending down into the duodenum.  Because of the
【36】patient's body habitus, it was difficult to maintain access for opacification,
【37】therefore, we re-punctured the common hepatic duct directly to maintain
【38】opacification of the bile ducts.  Further injection of contrast demonstrated
【39】small caliber right posterior ducts and these were targeted for definitive
【40】access.  One of the right posterior ducts was successfully accessed using a
【41】Cook 21-gauge needle and a Headliner wire passed through the needle into the
【42】more central biliary duct.  This confirmed an unusual anatomy with a very
【43】acute turn in the the right posterior duct as it conntected with the right
【44】anterior ductal system.  The Headliner wire passed centrally down into the
【45】common bile duct. The Cook needle was removed and exchanged for the inner
【46】portion of an AccuStick system.  The Headliner wire was removed and exchanged
【47】for a nitinol wire, which again passed into the common bile duct and duodenum.
【48】The inner portion of the AccuStick was removed and the AccuStick sheath was
【49】reassembled. This was then passed over the nitinol wire and positioned within
【50】the central intrahepatic duct.  The nitinol wire was removed and exchanged for
【51】___ wire.  The AccuStick sheath was removed and a 7 ___ 23 ___
【52】Tip sheath was selected and advanced over the ___ wire.  This was
【53】positioned within the central intrahepatic duct.  The ___ wire was
【54】exchanged for an Amplatz wire and a Lunderquist wire was also passed through
【55】the sheath as a safety wire.  The sheath was removed and advanced over the
【56】Lunderquist directly.  The indwelling biliary stent was positioned within one
【57】of the intrahepatic biliary ducts and could not be snared given its current
【58】condition.  Therefore, we selected a 10 mm x 4 ___ balloon.  This was
【59】positioned within the common bile duct and inflated while we advanced the
【60】balloon more distally.  This allowed us to displace the stent somewhat
【61】inferiorly giving us better access to try and snare the proximal end.  The
【62】balloon was removed and a GooseNeck snare device was advanced through the
